message: some new extension on FF don't need a restart, extension jetpack style
I would like that, but I'm curious: Is there a particular reason you don't want to distribute the app via the KBX?
It needs a restart to install the kbx, but not to install apps.
on FF4
knowing that I have to restart the browser to be able to use my extension often makes me think twice before installing it
correct me if I am wrong but firefox kbx extension doesn't need a FF restart
could that be implementeded for all the kynetx FF extensions?

It's Firefox thing. Installation or removal of an extension requires a restart of the browser. Kynetx application can however be installed and removed without restarting the browser once the KBX extension has been installed.
I was happy when I discovered that chrome could add and remove extensions on-the-fly.
Yes, that's true. We could rewrite the standalone extension to not require restart, but we're putting our energies into the KBX at this point, to enable dev mode for developer's apps, etc.
yes, once an app is popular, it gets downloaded a lot
yes I can feel KBX is your priority
and I won't complain!
Having said that, the standalone extension isn't complicated, so rewriting it jetpack style shouldn't be that hard.
who else thinks kynetx FF extension with no restart would be TERRIFIC
the really popular ones are downloaded tons, but they have been there for a long time.
or AWESOME to be more corporate
2 reasons
the other reason is linked to development with kbx which is more complicated to debug because of the sandbox. It seems I am the only one in that situation though
And their popularity is built.
i really want KBX to be the exclusive entry point in the future
to reach that i think we need other "catalog" websites, at least for the beginning
sorry, i try it again
per week?
I do see what you are getting at.
( don't know why the text is rendered that way)
how many time is the most popular app installed on KBX?
And I do love the idea of single built extensions leading to the marketplace.

I think ( just a hypothesis) that kynetx app extension could make it on mozilla addons website, 
at least some specially coded apps , and the mozilla addon website would give some visibility to kynetx and this would then drive traffic to kynetx market place
make KBX extension available on mozilla addon, that would be a good "trojan" :)
but it is also easy to fall into the numbers trap on extension installs.
We're working on that right now, we don't quite demand the same attention Google and Mozilla have so they could drive a lot of traffic to KBX.
How did you manage to get KBX on mozilla addons? KBX runs remote js code so what was the trick ?
@loic I don't believe that the Mozilla KBX has yet been review & approved. It's still in the sandbox.
@edorcutt so you believe mozilla would first publish the KBX and then review it ?
hmm....

@loic Yes. Anyone can create a developer account and publish an addon. Once the addon is published it is submitted for review. If the addon does not pass the review it is unlisted. This is the sequence of events that happened for the Hoverme addon.
